content.question:
In some species of bats, adult females regurgitate (bring up food from the stomach) to feed their young. In addition, adult bats regurgitate to feed other adults that have not recently eaten. The adults receiving the food may be unrelated bats who have previously participated in food sharing and are members of the same social group. Scientists claim that sharing among unrelated adult bats increases the fitness of the species.
Which of the following best supports the scientistsâ€™ claim?

choices.label: Bats that do not find food over a <math alttext="24" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>24</mn></math>-hour period may die, preventing their alleles from being passed on within the social group.
Bats that do not find food may adapt to eating other types of food, adding new alleles to the social group.
Food sharing reduces the number of unrelated animals that cluster in one area, thus increasing the genetic diversity in the social group.
Food sharing increases the number of unrelated animals that cluster in one area, thus decreasing competition for food among members of the social group.

content.answer: Bats that do not find food over a <math alttext="24" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>24</mn></math>-hour period may die, preventing their alleles from being passed on within the social group.

skill.text: 6.B: Support a claim with evidence from biological principles, concepts, processes, and data.
